issues.description: The no-argument constructor of Person has different visibility in the template and the solution. In the template Person() is declared public (allowing construction from other packages), whereas in the solution it is package-private. Code in the client (PersonScene and other packages) instantiates new Person() from a different package; making the constructor package-private will prevent those usages from compiling and blocks running the application. This is an unintentional structural change that breaks the expected cross-package instantiation of Person.
issues.suggested_fix: Restore a public no-argument constructor for Person in the common model (i.e., change the package-private 'Person() {}' in the solution to 'public Person() {}') so that code in other packages (client views/controllers) can instantiate Person objects as intended.

issues.description: The problem statement text incorrectly refers to the Consumer parameter type for PersonController methods as Consumer<List<Note>>. This is inconsistent with the actual intended API and template/solution code, which use Consumer<List<Person>> for PersonController methods. The typo in the problem description may confuse students about the expected parameter types they must implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the problem statement to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController method parameters so the textual description matches the code template and intended implementation.
